citation.article-title: Natronoincola histidinovorans gen. nov., sp. nov., A new alkaliphilic acetogenic anaerobe.

p.s: Description of Natronoincola histidinovorans sp. nov.
Natronoincola histidinovorans (hys ti di no vo rans: histidin, amino acid; vora, gobble: utilizing histidine as the main substrate)
Cells are flexible motile rods 0.7–1 x 2–6 μm, sometimes forming long filaments.
Motile by peritrichous flagella.
Multiplication by fission often unequal with occasional formation of terminal round mini-cells.
Asporogenous or oligosporic; spores, if present, round and terminal.
Fermentative.
Organotrophic.
Catabolic substrates are limited by histidine or glutamate involving CO-dehydrogenase pathway with acetate as a main product.
Ammonium is formed in large quantities.
Mesophilic.
Optimal growth at 37°C and maximal 45°C.
True alkaliphilic.
Optimal pH varies with the composition of medium: at medium of high alkalinity, optimum is at pH 9.4, with limits pH 8.0 to 10.5; in NaCl-medium it is at pH 8.5–8.7, with limits pH 7.9 to 9.2.
Moderately halophilic, growing at salinities not less than 4% NaCl but not higher than 16%, with optimum about 8–10%.
Obligately depends on sodium and bicarbonate ions.
G+C content of DNA for type strain Z-7940 is 31.9 mol% and for the strain Z-7939 is 32.3 mol% (optical reassociation).
Habitat: soda-depositing lakes.
The type strain Z-7940T and strain Z-7939 were isolated from desiccate of cyanobacterial bloom of Lake Magadi, Kenya.
The type strain was deposited with the Deutsche Sammlung von Mikroorganismen und Zellkulturen as strain DSMZ 11416T.
